properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally 15 cm or more in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: 60 km/h giving blowing snow over exposed areas. Locations: western Cape Breton, particularly the Highlands. Time span: today. Remarks: Flurries will continue, along with the potential for the development of snow squalls, as cold west to northwest winds persist over the region. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-04T00:38:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-03T08:39:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1705566151.2020
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill near minus 50 is expected tonight. Wind chill values are expected to moderate on Monday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-03T19:59:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-03T04:36:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4027588942.2020
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region, Aklavik Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. Concentrations of fine particulate matter will remain high tonight. They should gradually decrease Monday morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-03T21:59:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-02-03T03:34:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2355154582.2020
Area: Saint-Jérôme area, Lachute area, Saint-Eustache area, Longueuil - Varennes area, Laval area, Montréal Island area, Châteauguay - La Prairie area, Soulanges area, Vaudreuil area, Saint-Rémi area, Valleyfield - Beauharnois area, Hemmingford area, Huntingdon area, Berthierville - Saint-Gabriel area, Rawdon - Joliette area, Mascouche area, Sorel - Yamaska area, Saint-Hyacinthe - Acton Vale area, Verchères - Beloeil area, Saint-Jean - Marieville area, Lacolle area

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: near 5 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity. Time span: continuing until overnight. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strong northwesterly winds to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. The snow and winds will taper off overnight. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-04T00:40:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-03T08:41:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2326586491.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm except up to 25 cm possible on the western side of the Great Northern Peninsula Locations: western Newfoundland and the Great Northern Peninsula. Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h. Time span: continuing until overnight. Remarks: Snow combined with strong winds will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Snow and blowing snow will taper off this evening in the Bay St. George and Corner Brook area and overnight for the Great Northern Peninsula. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-04T00:43:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-03T08:44:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1852088251.2020
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Visibilities will be reduced to near zero in blowing snow until Monday afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 15 centimetres are expected with northerly winds gusting at times up to 80 kilometres per hour, causing widespread blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-03T19:30:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-03T03:31:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3218714583.2020
Area: Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: westerly 70 km/h, except 100 km/h in the Canada Bay area. Time span: this afternoon until overnight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-04T00:40:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-03T08:41:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3195897491.2020
Area: Northern Peninsula East
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Further snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h from the northwest this afternoon. Locations: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Snow will continue to combine with strong winds to reduce visibilities in blowing snow today. Conditions are expected to improve this evening as the snow tapers off. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-04T01:01:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-03T09:02:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1043373913.2020
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Heavy snow and blowing snow today and tonight. Total snowfall: 30 to 45 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 100 km/h along the coast this afternoon through tonight. Locations: Makkovik to Black Tickle. Time span: continuing until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will combine with strong winds to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve around midday on Tuesday as the snow tapers off and the winds ease. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-04T00:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-03T09:00:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2625727824.2020
Area: Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 40 cm except up to 50 cm possible on the western side of the Great Northern Peninsula Locations: western Newfoundland and the Great Northern Peninsula. Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h. Time span: continuing until Monday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to redevelop in the southwest this evening as winds continue to shift to northerly. The fresh snow combined with strong winds will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Snow and blowing snow will taper off Monday evening in the Bay St. George and Corner Brook area and overnight Monday along the Great Northern Peninsula. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-03T11:33:13-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Further snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 70 km/h. Time span: continuing through this evening. Remarks: Snow will continue to combine with strong northwesterly winds to reduce visibilities in blowing snow today. Conditions are expected to improve around midnight tonight as the snow tapers off. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
